channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Bolivian Town Drifts from President, Despite Promises Kept to Leftists
item.description: Residents of Cobija, which has prospered under ​President​ Evo Morales, expect his left-wing policies to continue even though he was denied the chance to seek another term.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Evo Morales School in Cobija, a $650,000 project that was never completed because a developer vanished after receiving money from the government.

item.title: Yemeni Civilians Killed by Airstrike on Market, Witnesses Say
item.description: At least 30 people were reported dead after a bombing by the Arab coalition that could add to calls for an international arms embargo on Saudi Arabia.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Ex-Official Calls for Malaysian Prime Minister to Step Down
item.description: A Malaysian official who has been removed from a top party job said he had seen proof that Prime Minister Najib Razak committed a crime related to the country’s sovereign wealth fund.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.media:description: Malaysia’s former deputy prime minister, Muhyiddin Yassin, with prime minister, Najib Razak, in Kuala Lumpur last year.

item.title: Italy Growers Wary of Olive Oil Fraud as New Law Is Weighed
item.description: Olive oil producers in the nation are troubled by draft legislation that would tinker with penalties for passing off counterfeit olive oil and its origin.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicola Fazzi, the director of the Colli Etruschi cooperative, among a member’s olive trees in Blera, Italy. He called a draft decree an attempt to “decriminalize adulterated oil.”

item.title: Monarch Butterfly Migration Rebounds, Easing Some Fears
item.description: Monarch butterflies, which fly each year to Mexico from Canada and the United States, covered about 10 acres this winter, an area more than three times as large as last year.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT
item.media:description: Monarch butterflies last year in Mexico. They fly more than 2,500 miles south each year from Canada and the United States.

item.title: Scientists Protest Cuts and Commercialization at Australian Climate Center
item.description: A decision by Australia’s science agency to lay off researchers and focus more on commerce threatens climate studies around the globe.
item.category: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (Australia)
United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: Staff cutbacks and a shift in focus threaten climate work done at the Cape Grim research station in Tasmania, Australia.

item.title: Assassination of Putin Critic Remembered in Moscow
item.description: Tens of thousands of people joined a solemn march on Saturday to commemorate the first anniversary of the assassination of Boris Y. Nemtsov, a Russian opposition leader.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO
item.media:description: Thousands in Moscow marched to mark the anniversary of the death of Boris Y. Nemtsov, a former deputy prime minister, on Saturday.

item.title: Talk Grows About Who Will Succeed Palestinians’ Fading Mahmoud Abbas
item.description: The aging Palestinian president, likened to a tree with leaves blowing off, rules ineffectively over a divided people and failing institutions.
item.category: Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Mahmoud Abbas, center, after meeting with John Kerry in Amman, Jordan, last Sunday.

item.title: Early Results Show Reformists and Moderates Drawing Votes in Iran Elections
item.description: Preliminary results released Saturday showed that reformist and moderate candidates were leading in one of the two elections just held by Iran, state news media quoted the Interior Ministry as saying.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: A polling station in Qom, Iran, on Friday. More than 30 million Iranians voted on Friday in two elections, one for a new Parliament and the other for an influential clerical council.

item.title: Early Tallies Show Irish Voters Rejecting Government
item.description: The governing coalition will lose too many seats in Parliament to retain power, but it is unclear if any party will have enough seats to form a government.
item.dc:creator: DOUGLAS DALBY
item.media:description: Sealed ballot boxes at the Royal Dublin Society center in the Irish capital, on Saturday.

item.title: The Killing Fields of South Sudan
item.description: Atrocities are being committed by a government that the United States has helped establish.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Violence in Syria Abates on Day 1 of Cease-Fire
item.description: Fighting decreased significantly in the country following a truce brokered by the United States and Russia, though there were reports of scattered violations.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Syrians collected items from an abandoned building on Saturday in Douma, near Damascus.

item.title: Suicide Bombings in Afghanistan Kill at Least 26
item.description: The two attacks, in Kabul and Kunar Province, also wounded nearly 50 people days ahead of expected talks between the government and the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and JAWAD SUKHANYAR
item.media:description: Afghan mourners carried the coffin of the victim of a suicide attack in Kunar Province on Saturday.

item.title: Elias Demetracopoulos, Journalist Who Linked Greek Junta to Nixon Campaign, Dies at 87
item.description: The enigmatic Mr. Demetracopoulos often exasperated the State Department, once sued the C.I.A. and was honored in his homeland as a champion of freedom.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS
item.media:description: Elias P. Demetracopoulos in an undated photo.

item.title: U.N. Security Council Endorses Truce Deal for Syria
item.description: “It is, potentially, a historic junction,” the United Nations mediator, Staffan de Mistura, said of the cease-fire negotiated by the United States and Russia.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: A wounded boy was brought into a makeshift hospital in the rebel-held city of Douma, Syria, on Friday.

item.title: News Analysis: Syria Truce Comes With Price, but Not for Assad
item.description: European and Israeli intelligence officials believe the pause in fighting may consolidate President Bashar al-Assad’s hold on power.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: A Syrian boy in a hospital bed on Friday. He was injured in Syrian government airstrikes on the rebel-held area of Douma, east of Damascus. A cease-fire went into effect at midnight.

item.title: Shabab Militants Claim Deadly Attack on Hotel in Somalia
item.description: At least 10 people were killed and dozens were wounded in an attack on a hotel and public garden in Mogadishu. Security forces managed to stop militants from storming the building, officials said.
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED IBRAHIM
item.media:description: A injured man after an attack at the SYL Hotel in Mogadishu, Somalia, on Friday.

item.title: Shabab Militants Claim Deadly Attack on Hotel in Somalia
item.description: At least 10 people were killed and dozens were wounded in an attack on a hotel and public garden in Mogadishu. Security forces managed to stop militants from storming the building, officials said.
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED IBRAHIM
item.media:description: A injured man after an attack at the SYL Hotel in Mogadishu, Somalia, on Friday.

item.title: Questions Nag in Sweden 30 Years After Leader’s Assassination
item.description: The unsolved shooting of Prime Minister Olof Palme in 1986 was a watershed moment in history that continues to fascinate and haunt the country.
item.dc:creator: DAVID CROUCH
item.media:description: The site in Stockholm where Prime Minister Olof Palme of Sweden was gunned down on Feb. 28, 1986, in a photograph taken the next day.

item.title: Gianni Infantino to Lead FIFA Into New Era
item.description: Mr. Infantino defeated three other candidates in an election that many soccer officials hope will be a new beginning for the embattled soccer body.
item.dc:creator: SAM BORDEN
item.media:description: Gianni Infantino, second from right, with his main rival, Sheikh Salman bin Ebrahim al-Khalifa.
